awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dust, Gas, and Star Formation: Synthesizing 20 Years of Radio, Millimeter, and Infrared Surveys
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxies grow by converting interstellar gas into new generations of stars. A main step in that process is the conversion of low-density, atomic gas into cold, dense, star-forming clouds. Interstellar dust controls this process by shielding gas from destructive ultraviolet radiation and promoting chemical reactions. The abundance of both dust and cold gas depend on local environment in a galaxy, but the nature of this dependence is still debated at a very basic level. This project will test competing hypotheses for what sets the amount of dust and cold gas in galaxies by mapping dust, neutral interstellar gas (diffuse atomic gas and cold, dense molecular gas), and local conditions in a sample of nearby galaxies ten times larger than those used in previous studies. The investigators will use these observations database to answer two questions about gas and star formation in galaxies.  The first question is what sets the amount of cold, star-forming gas?  The second question is what determines the abundance of dust? These two intertwined questions are critical to understand how galaxies grow and change over time.

The investigators will assemble the next generation database of dust and gas distributions in galaxies. To do this, they will combine new and archival observations of atomic hydrogen (HI) from the NSF-funded Very Large Array with Herschel spacecraft measurements of the distribution and properties of interstellar dust.  They will increase, by an order of magnitude, the sample of galaxies with such observations.  An order of magnitude increase in the set of galaxies studied in this way will advance the field into a new regime of statistical hypothesis testing, a potentially transformative step in understanding the physics of gas in galaxies.

The observing database will be shared on the internet with other astronomers and also the public.  The investigators will build on the Zooniverse project to share their observations with the public.  Zooniverse is an internet tool that allows the public to view and classify scientific observations.  With this tool, the public can both appreciate the observations and aid in the research. The investigators plan to create 'the HI Holes Project', in which volunteer citizen scientists will identify giant holes in the gaseous interstellar medium of real and simulated galaxies.

por.por_cntn:
Prior to forming new stars, gas in the interstellar medium (ISM) of galaxies must reach high densities and cool temperatures to allow gravitational collapse of gas into stars. In this process, low density gas where hydrogen is primarily atomic becomes denser and eventually transitions to being primarily molecular. The physics of this process are critical to understanding how galaxies form new stars out of their reservoir of interstellar gas. Dust grains appear to play a key role in this process because they block the molecule-dissociating UV radiation from other nearby young stars and they provide a catalyst for the chemical reaction that creates molecular hydrogen. 

In this project, our goal was to provide new and comprehensive measurements of the amount of dust relative to gas in the ISM of nearby galaxies and to characterize the role dust plays in the transition from atomic to molecular gas.  To do this, we uniformly analyzed large datasets of nearby galaxy mapping at infrared, millimeter, and radio wavelengths. In particular, we used infrared observations tracing dust emission from the Wide Field Infrared Sky Explorer and the Herschel Space Observatory; millimeter observations tracing molecular gas from several observatories including the Atacama Large Millimeter Array; and radio observations tracing atomic hydrogen from the Very Large Array. In total, we have created maps of the dust mass for approximately 1000 galaxies and maps of the atomic hydrogen for approximately 500 galaxies and of the molecular gas for approximately 200 galaxies.  We are in the process of preparing these reduced datasets for permanent archiving and producing a suite of high level public data products.  We have also used the maps to facilitate a number of investigations into the state of the gas and dust in galaxies.

The resulting data have been used to make comprehensive investigations of (1) the behavior of the dust-to-gas and dust-to-metals ratio in galaxies (Chiang et al. 2018, 2021), (2) the small scale structure of dust temperature, composition, and distribution of dust in galaxies (Chastenet et al. 2019, Utomo et al. 2019), (3) the structure and amount of atomic and molecular gas in galaxies (Koch et al. 2019, 2020, Leroy et al. 2022), and (4) the structure of the interstellar medium and the relation of interstellar gas pressure, molecular cloud properties, and phase balance in galaxy disks (Sun et al. 2020, 2022). Together, these results have revealed that (A) the properties and structure of dust change dramatically on small scales but follow clear patterns with understandable physical explanations, (B) the fraction of heavy elements depleted into dust shows a clear dependence on environment and has an important interrelationship with the methods used to estimate the gas mass in galaxies, (C) that despite some claims to the contrary, astronomers do not appear to have missed an entire hidden phase of interstellar gas, and (D) that the atomic, molecular, and stellar structure of galaxy disks are closely intertwined. The work has already resulted in the release of a number of rich public data products, with more planned in the near future.
